title: About
text:
I am a PhD student at the QUT Centre for Data Science (in Brisbane, Australia) working with Distinguished Professor Kerrie Mengersen on methods for Bayesian federated learning and differentially private generative models. My thesis is currently under internal review.
From May to November 2024, I am relocating to Melbourne to complete an internship with the machine learning research team at Amazon. In December, I am moving to Finland to begin a postdoctoral position with Professor Sami Kaski and others at Aalto University (affiliated with the Probabilistic Machine Learning group and FCAI.
My research interests include variational inference, generative models, federated and distributed algorithms, latent-variable models, and Bayesian deep learning.
In the past, I have worked as a research data scientist at WearOptimo, a biotechnology startup developing microwearable devices, and completed internships in quantitative trading, consulting and at a national scientific institute. I have also worked as a research assistant and tutored seven courses in mathematics and statistics, from beginner to Master’s level. I am well-versed in using automatic differentiation libraries like JAX and PyTorch, as well as probabilistic programming libraries such as NumPyro, PyMC, Pyro, and Stan.
Contact me at conorhassan.ai@gmail.com and connect with me on LinkedIn, X, and GitHub!

title: Publications
text:
Conor Hassan, Robert Salomone, and Kerrie Mengersen. “Federated Variational Inference Methods for Structured Latent Variable Models.” arXiv preprint arXiv:2302.03314 (2023). Under review.
Conor Hassan, Robert Salomone, and Kerrie Mengersen. “Deep Generative Models, Synthetic Tabular Data, and Differential Privacy: An Overview and Synthesis.” arXiv preprint arXiv:2307.15424 (2023).
Conor Hassan, et al. “Deep Generative Priors for Dependent Data Federated Learning.” In preparation.
Conor Hassan, et al. “Bayesian Vertical Federated Learning via Data Augmentation.” In preparation.
Joshua J. Bon, et al. “Being Bayesian in the 2020s: opportunities and challenges in the practice of modern applied Bayesian statistics.” Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A (2023). Accepted for publication.
